_prev_prog_3.Description: The Westbrook plant chlorine process has one covered chemical, chlorine, (Cl2).  Cl2 is pruchased in 90 ton rail cars and is used to bleach kraft pulp and as a biocide for the mill water system.  The prevention program covers the Cl2 unloading, vaporization, absorption with water, Cl2 delivery system to the bleach plant where it first mixes with the pulp, delivery of chlorine gas to mill areas for water treatment, and the Cl2 gas process gas scrubber.  The plan consists of engineered systems and a management system.  Engineered systems include ventilation of all storage tanks to the process gas scrubber, and Cl2 alarms that trigger at 1ppm.  In addition, the plant is operated by a modern Foxboro DCS (distributed control system) in which the process is automatically shut down if critical process parameter limits are exceeded or if critical process sensors fail.  The plant has an onsite HAZMAT team and conducts annual response training exercises with the local fire and police departments as well as other responders.  The plant also maintains a gas dispersion modeling system using real time meteorological data.  The management system is based on the 14 aspects of OSHA's PSM program found in CFR 1910.119.

The Westbrook plants chlorine dioxide process has one covered chemical, chlorine dioxide (ClO2).  ClO2 is produced onsite and is used to bleach kraft pulp.  The prevention program covers the ClO2 generating plant, the ClO2 delivery system to the bleach plant where it first mixes with the pulp and the ClO2 gas scrubber.  The plan consists of engineered systems and a management system.  Engineered systems include ventilation of all storage tanks to the ClO2 absorbtion tower, safety relief systems on the storage tanks, and generators and ClO2 alarms that trigger at 0.1 ppm.  In addition, the plant is operated by a modern Foxboro DCS (distributed control system) in which the process is automatically shut down if critical process parameter limits are exceeded or if critical process sensors fail.  The plant has an onsite HAZMAT team and conducts annual response training exercises with the local fire and police departments as well as other responders.  The plant also maintains a gas dispersion modeling systemusing real time meteorological data.  The management system is based on the 14 aspects of OSHA's PSM program found in CFR 1910.119.

S.D. Warren Company
Westbrook Mill

I. Executive Summary

A. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies 

S.D. Warren Company is committed to operating its integrated pulp and paper mill in Westbrook, Maine in an environmentally responsible manner and to providing a safe work place for its employees and the surrounding community.  As part of this commitment to environmental stewardship and employee safety, Westbrook has developed and implemented numerous environmental and safety programs that are designed to eliminate and/or drastically reduce the potential for accidental releases.  S.D. Warren  has also developed and implemented a number of programs that are designed to ensure that if an accidental release occurs, it will be handled in a manner that minimizes adverse impact to people, the environment and the mill.  Many of these programs have been in place since the late 1980s. 

S.D. Warren believes that safety, health and environmental protection are essential to responsibly operating its facilities.  S.D. Warren is submitting this Risk Management Plan for chlorine and chlorine dioxide processes ("covered processes") in use at the Westbrook mill as of June 21, 1999.  Following closure of these covered processes, the use of chlorine and chlorine dioxide at the mill will be discontinued.  S.D. Warren expects to file an amendment to this plan indicating that it is no longer subject to the RMP rule.  

S.D. Warren views accident prevention, and personnel and environmental protection as a continuous  process.  Consequently, S.D. Warren continuously strives to improve its accident prevention, environmental protection and emergency response programs.  A recent addition to S.D. Warrens overall accident prevention and response program is the development of the Westbrook mills Risk Management Program. The maximum amount of chlorine in a covered process is 360,000 lbs.  The maximum amount of chlorine in a single stationary source is 180,000 pounds. The maximum amount of chlorine dioxide in a covered process is 1667 pounds.  The maximum amount of chlorine dioxide in a covered process is 833.5 pounds.

C. Off-site Consequence Analysis

An off-site consequence analysis is required by the RMP rule to estimate potential impacts to the community.  As required by RMP, Westbrooks off-site consequence analysis included evaluation of a worst-case accidental release for all toxic chemicals and an alternative release for each covered chemical.

A worst-case release is defined by EPA as "a release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance to an endpoint defined in ' 68.22."  40 C.F.R. ' 68.3.   EPA requires the worst-case accidental release to be modeled using highly conservative meteorological data designed to result in the maximum possible adverse impact.  For example, EPA requires worst-case models to be based on the hottest day of the year, occurring at night with a very slow, steady wind which would not disperse a release very effectively. Further, the model assumes that the entire contents of the largest vessel is released instantaneously.  According to the chlorine institute, no 90-ton rail car has ever instantaneously released its contents, and the chances of such an event occurring in Maine on a 960F night when the wind is blowing at 3.4 miles per hour are extremely remote.  

Under the EPA mandated scenario described above, the worst-case release at the mill (for purposes of RMP) would result in a vapor cloud that could extend beyond the mills property line.

Westbrook developed alternative scenarios for chlorine and chlorine dioxide which focus on more realistic release scenarios occurring during more commo

n meteorological conditions.  However, EPA requires modeling of a release which could impact off-site locations. After considering all criteria in the RMP rule, Westbrook chose the following alternative release scenarios.  The chlorine release scenario was modeled on the occurrence of a pinhole leak in the liquid chlorine line which would result in a vapor cloud that could extend beyond the mills property line.  The chlorine dioxide alternative release scenario was based on the failure of an adequate water supply to be available during the chlorine dioxide production process which would result in a vapor cloud that could extend beyond the mills property line.    

D. Accident Release Prevention Program

Westbrook  has developed an accidental release prevention program that is designed and implemented to drastically reduce the possibility of an accidental catastrophic release.   The program complies with the requirements of OSHAs Process Safety Management rule found at 29 C.F.R. Part 1910.119 and analogous RMP requirements found at 40 C.F.R. Part 68, Subpart D.  To comply with the RMP rule, the mill has taken its existing PSM program and incorporated an additional focusprotection of the public.  

The basic elements of  Westbrooks prevention program are described below: 

1. Employee Participation.  Westbrook  has developed and implements a written plan of action regarding employee participation in the safety and accident prevention process.  The plan describes how employees are:  (A)  consulted and what input they will have in the development of Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) and other PSM and RMP safety elements; and (B) given access to PSM and RMP information at the mill.   

2. Process Safety Information.  In accordance with applicable requirements, Westbrook  has compiled and maintains  process safety information about the design, installation, maintenance, and operations of its covered processes.  This ensures that information remains current.

13. Compliance Audits.  Westbrook has evaluated its compliance with OSHAs PSM Standard at least every three years to verify that the procedures and practices it has developed are adequate and being followed.  

14. Trade Secrets.  Westbrook makes all necessary information available to those persons responsible for compiling process safety information and those assisting in the development of the process hazard analysis. 

E. Five Year Accident History

The Westbrook mill has not experienced a RMP reportable incident from a covered process during the last five years.

F. Emergency Response Procedures and Policies

Westbrook maintains a fully trained Hazardous Materials Response Team and Fire Brigade that is on-site 365 days a year, 24 hours a day.  These teams are capable of minimizing the adverse impact from reasonably foreseeable accidental releases that may occur. 

In the unlikely event that an accidental release occurs that is beyond the capabilities of Westbrooks Hazardous Material Response Team and Fire Brigade, the mill has entered into informal mutual aid agreements with the Westbrook Fire and Police Departments, Maine Medical Center, and Med-Cu ambulance services.  The mutual aid agreements provide that these entities are available to respond to emergencies at the Westbrook mill upon request by Westbrook.  The Westbrook Fire Department operates under mutual aid agreements with the cities of Portland and South Portland and with the towns of Windham, 
Gorham, Falmouth, and Scarborough to ensure that additional  emergency response personnel and equipment are available to respond to a significant release at the mill.
